docs.filename: NLC Migration - Macquarie Refinance Payout Process.docx
docs.content:
**Purpose**

The purpose of this document is to outline the process for obtaining a
payout for Macquarie funded leases for refinances.

**Scope**

This report outlines the process of obtaining a payout for NLC migration
refinances funded with Macquarie only.

**Process**

1.  Follow normal quote process with customer, assuming the residual in
    miles is correct.

2.  Once you receive the signed quote **[or]{.underline}** the finance
    application, please send a request to Shannon or Andy who will
    obtain a Macquarie leasing RV tax invoice -- **Note this does
    [not]{.underline} have to be done in the last month of the lease**

3.  Please include customer name and Macquarie contract number in the
    request -- this can be obtained from the financier section in miles
    (Where we enter the AI number) -- Format is 001-XXXXXXX-00X

4.  Document will be provided within two business days

5.  Please note this is mandatory to obtain before passing the file down
    to settlements.

**Disputes**

Any queries or disputes can be referred to Novated Sales team
leadership.

**Purpose**

The purpose of this document is to outline the process and requirements
for quoting Autonomy

**Scope**

This report outlines the process to outline which employers, the
variances between Autonomy and CBA policies and the benefits of using
Autonomy

**Process**

Autonomy differences to CBA:

-   Different HEMS cancellations -- we are not provided these figures
    either so you would want a generally want a pretty good surplus. You
    can switch to CBA before sending

-   Autonomy cannot edit customer data. If a customer enters rent and
    mortgage, the app must be sent back to the customer to remove the
    double up, same situation as if they review living expenses and need
    to amend or miss adding a credit card

-   Autonomy do not accept manual forms. I would now refrain from
    sending the form and move to an "only if required" process. If you
    receive a manual form, you will either need to switch to CBA or ask
    the customer to recomplete in the online application

-   Autonomy do not accept contracts of employment for settlement, they
    require payslips only and will only settle once these can be
    provided (can be conditioned)

-   Autonomy do not accept high kilometre residuals -- the system will
    not allow you to quote this so please use CBA

-   Autonomy currently do not currently accept used vehicles, if there
    is ever a question new vs used, default to CBA

-   If servicing is evident, updated approvals will be instant. Simply
    go to finance application manager, enter the new quote number and
    the approval will do to IMS

-   The internal worksheet is not required for Autonomy, just attach the
    licence and payslip to the IMS case, but the worksheet will not be
    attached as it is not required.

**Please note Online application does not work on NAB systems (must do
on personal computer) as well as some government systems -- so ensure
people are doing on personal devices. Note the mobile application is
also not great so best on a desktop or laptop.**

The following employers are enabled for Autonomy please default to them
in all allowable circumstances:

+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Essential Energy (600148)                                         |
+=======================================================================+
| -   AMES Australasia Pty Ltd (AUCY0013)                               |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Boart Longyear Australia Pty Ltd (AUBO0129)                       |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Byron Shire Council (AUBY0013)                                    |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (AUAU0088)             |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Australian Federal Police (AUAU0704)                              |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Clearview Administration Services Pty Limited (AUCL0100)          |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Mingara Recreation Club limited (AUMI0676)                        |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Greater Western Water (AUCI0044)                                  |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   City Of Greater Bendigo (AUCI0038)                                |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Seqirus Pty Ltd (AUCS0070)                                        |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   CSL Limited (AUCS0071)                                            |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Colac Otway Shire Council (AUCO0577)                              |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Commonwealth Bank of Australia (AUCO0603)                         |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Elders Rural Services Australia Limited (751964)                  |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Elders Limited (751971)                                           |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   B. & W. Rural Pty Limited (751973)                                |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   First Sentier Investors (Australia) Services Pty Ltd (745926)     |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Elders Financial Planning Pty Ltd (751975)                        |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   National Australia Bank Limited (AUNA0102)                        |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Ausgrid Management Pty Limited (719167)                           |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   The Summerland Credit Union Limited (AUSU0068)                    |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Jacobs Group (Australia) Pty Limited (S0001)                      |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   ABC Sheds Global Pty Ltd (749464)                                 |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Queensland Treasury Corporation (AUQU0033)                        |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   ACT Government - Shared Services Finance (AUSH0039)               |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Northrop Grumman Australia Pty Limited (AUNO0324)                 |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Northrop Grumman Integrated Defence Services Pty Limited          |
|     (AUNO0328)                                                        |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Northrop Grumman M5 Network Security Pty Ltd (AUNO0456)           |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Department of Defence (AUDE0787)                                  |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Intergraph Corporation Pty Ltd (C10161)                           |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Smith & Nephew Pty Ltd (C10296)                                   |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Accident Compensation Conciliation Service (C10002)               |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Australian Radio Network (C10715)                                 |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   The Hills Shire Council (774656)                                  |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Truis Pty Ltd (776358)                                            |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
| -   Muswellbrook Shire Council (777580)                               |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------+

**Please note you can also use Autonomy for NAB if CBA decline first**

**How to quote Autonomy**

**Miles**

In the services - \> Finance -\> Funding arrangements. From here untick
CBA and tick Autonomy

![](media/image1.png){width="6.268055555555556in"
height="3.4166666666666665in"}

\***Note that if you change model, or if the template drops out, it will
drop back to default to CBA**\*

**In QuoMo**

**\
Go to contract tab -\> Funder where there is a dropdown**

![](media/image2.png){width="4.779166666666667in"
height="3.151388888888889in"}

**Select Autonomy**

**Note**: Contract number is the AFLT number inside the payment tab
where we add the AI number. You may need to check different lines to
find this - No worksheet required.

![cid:image004.jpg@01D77D5D.5D7A84E0](media/image3.jpeg){width="6.268055555555556in"
height="2.7618055555555556in"}

**Disputes**

Any queries or disputes can be referred to Novated Sales team
leadership.

**[Check List]{.underline}**

**Customer details**

1.  Check full name matches Licence

2.  Check DOB matches Licence

3.  Check address matches Licence

**If any of the details do not match, please clarify with the customer,
and obtain further documents if possible (marriage certificate for name,
utility bill for address)**

**Pay details**

1.  Check employer name on payslip matches employer on finance
    application.

2.  Check salary on payslip matches salary on application

3.  Check for deductions which may need to be clarified (current lease,
    voluntary super, etc)

**Watch for employers with multiple entities. If the details do not
match please seek clarification from the customer.**

**Application details**

1.  Has the customer declared rent & mortgage? If so, please clarify if
    this is correct

2.  Has the customer declared other expenses for investment properties
    as well as investment property mortgage repayments? If so, please
    clarify if this is correct

3.  Does total net salary declared exceed total expenses including
    proposed lease repayment? -- If no may require addition income (see
    below)

4.  Do the mortgage limits equal the mortgage balances? -- If not please
    clarify that the mortgage limit is not the initial loan amount but
    the amount, they have available immediately. These are generally the
    same.

5.  Has the applicant declared any credit cards? If no, please ask them
    if they have any credit cards even with a \$0 balance and to declare
    limit and financier

**The application can be moved to customer edit by your manager so the
customer can fix these details, or details can be obtained from the
customer through email, or recorded call and provided to CBA once
submitted.**

**Acceptable documentation**

1.  2 x payslips within the last 90 days

2.  Employment contract signed by employee and employer if they have not
    yet begun employment.

3.  2 x Rental statements within the last 90 days or income tax return
    (with TFN blacked out) for rental income

4.  2 x years of bonus payslips

5.  Driver's licence, passport, or proof of age card

6.  Utility bill as proof of address (phone bill, council rates, bank
    statement, etc)

**\*\*Please ensure there are no documents with the TFN included such as
Income Statement, Notice of Assessment or Tax Return -- if so, please
ask your TL to remove\*\***

**Process**

**Step 1: Creating the driver**

-   Request screen

-   Click New

-   Customer or Cost centre (Employer)

-   Driver (Customer name)

-   Complete driver up top

-   Use selected driver if they are in the system (ensure its driver) --
    otherwise "Create "Driver" down the bottom

-   Click Pencil to edit details

-   Change from contact to person

-   Enter Name, Mobile and email

-   Press okay

-   Save (up top left or ctrl S)

**Step 2: Creating the quote -- general tab**

-   Click on request tab down the bottom

-   Click "Plus" button on the right

-   Use template -- T2P if available otherwise New docs

-   Select "vehicle procurement type" as per quote

-   Select vehicle (make, model type)

-   Enter Duration

-   Enter Total distance

-   Enter Registration postcode

-   Enter Salary

-   Answer insurance / leaseguard questions

-   Enter accessories (dealer and aftermarket)

**Step 3: Matching the quote -- Vehicle tab**

-   Check list price in miles vs dealer quote. If miles is higher, enter
    difference in a second discount field. If miles is lower, enter
    difference in transport costs

-   Go to discount tab and enter vehicle discount in dealer discount

-   Go to delivery costs tab and match all onroads and dealer delivery

-   **\*\*If NSW -- Dealers do not quote CTP, allow system to quote CTP
    and ensure CIC Allianz is in provider column\*\***

-   **Ensure "Dealer On Road" = Dealer price quoted for procurement (If
    NSW -- you must -- CTP off from the dealer on road in miles)**

**Step 4: Complete running costs -- Lease services tab**

-   Adjust services within your DA (+/- 20% for fuel maitnenacne tyres,
    unlimited for rego)

-   Add or remove services such as Leaseguard, roadside and own
    insurance by hitting the edit pencil on the right

**Step 5: Finalisation**

-   Hit validate up the top

-   Press New document

-   Novated Quote - \> Next - \> Preview

-   Save quote

**Quoting used cars**

When quoting a used car, it is generally best to go straight into the
backend of the search by selecting the magnifying glass in the type
section

![](media/image1.png){width="6.268055555555556in" height="2.83125in"}

**Inside here, I would ensure my selection is "List of Active and New
CatalogVehicles"**

**Search using Model of vehicle, then relevant model year as below:**

**Model = i30**

**Description = %MY18%**

![](media/image2.png){width="6.268055555555556in"
height="3.463888888888889in"}

**Fill in all details as per a new quote, then go to vehicle tab and
changed "Purchase Type" to used vehicle**

![](media/image3.png){width="6.268055555555556in"
height="4.280555555555556in"}

Change list price to 1/11 of asking price of vehicle, do to amount
excluding gst.

E.g. for a car worth \$30,000, divide this by 1.1 and enter in list
price

30,000 / 1.1 = 27,272.73

![](media/image4.png){width="6.268055555555556in"
height="2.6368055555555556in"}

Go to delivery tab and enter Build date, First registration date,
registration expiry and current Odo

![](media/image5.png){width="6.268055555555556in" height="3.05in"}

If unsure, use the below:

Build Date -- Start year of car model -- 01/01/2018

First registration date -- Start year of car model -- 01/01/2018

Registration expiry -- Start year of next calendar year (as long as the
car has registration) -- 01/01/2022

Current Odometer -- Get from vehicle if possible

If the vehicle does not include on roads, please ensure "System OTR
Pricing is ticked"

![](media/image6.png){width="6.268055555555556in"
height="3.251388888888889in"}

This will calculate the stamp duty required relevant to the price and
state.

If is a dealer quote, un tick box and match on roads as per dealer
quote.

If the vehicle is a private sale and we need to pay on roads to the
customer. We will need to add a supplier next to the on-road costs.

Firstly, press the + button next to workflow, then process

![](media/image7.png){width="6.268055555555556in"
height="3.3944444444444444in"}

Next create Novated Customer off the driver contract and then start
process

![](media/image8.png){width="6.268055555555556in"
height="2.6930555555555555in"}

Then add to provider box by either searching back end, or entering last
name and adding last name followed by a %

![](media/image9.png){width="6.268055555555556in"
height="3.263888888888889in"}

Now the provider is in here it will prompt onraods to go to driver.

![](media/image10.png){width="6.268055555555556in"
height="3.3666666666666667in"}

docs.content:
# Claude prompting guide

## General tips for effective prompting

### 1. Be clear and specific
   - Clearly state your task or question at the beginning of your message.
   - Provide context and details to help Claude understand your needs.
   - Break complex tasks into smaller, manageable steps.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Help me with a presentation."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I need help creating a 10-slide presentation for our quarterly sales meeting. The presentation should cover our Q2 sales performance, top-selling products, and sales targets for Q3. Please provide an outline with key points for each slide."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt provides specific details about the task, including the number of slides, the purpose of the presentation, and the key topics to be covered.

### 2. Use examples
   - Provide examples of the kind of output you're looking for.
   - If you want a specific format or style, show Claude an example.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Write a professional email."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I need to write a professional email to a client about a project delay. Here's a similar email I've sent before:

   'Dear [Client],
   I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to update you on the progress of [Project Name]. Unfortunately, we've encountered an unexpected issue that will delay our completion date by approximately two weeks. We're working diligently to resolve this and will keep you updated on our progress.
   Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.
   Best regards,
   [Your Name]'

   Help me draft a new email following a similar tone and structure, but for our current situation where we're delayed by a month due to supply chain issues."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt provides a concrete example of the desired style and tone, giving Claude a clear reference point for the new email.

### 3. Encourage thinking
   - For complex tasks, ask Claude to "think step-by-step" or "explain your reasoning."
   - This can lead to more accurate and detailed responses.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "How can I improve team productivity?"
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I'm looking to improve my team's productivity. Think through this step-by-step, considering the following factors:
   1. Current productivity blockers (e.g., too many meetings, unclear priorities)
   2. Potential solutions (e.g., time management techniques, project management tools)
   3. Implementation challenges
   4. Methods to measure improvement

   For each step, please provide a brief explanation of your reasoning. Then summarize your ideas at the end."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt asks Claude to think through the problem systematically, providing a guided structure for the response and asking for explanations of the reasoning process. It also prompts Claude to create a summary at the end for easier reading.

### 4. Iterative refinement
   - If Claude's first response isn't quite right, ask for clarifications or modifications.
   - You can always say "That's close, but can you adjust X to be more like Y?"

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Make it better."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "That’s a good start, but please refine it further. Make the following adjustments:
   1. Make the tone more casual and friendly
   2. Add a specific example of how our product has helped a customer
   3. Shorten the second paragraph to focus more on the benefits rather than the features"
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt provides specific feedback and clear instructions for improvements, allowing Claude to make targeted adjustments instead of just relying on Claude’s innate sense of what “better” might be — which is likely different from the user’s definition!

### 5. Leverage Claude's knowledge
   - Claude has broad knowledge across many fields. Don't hesitate to ask for explanations or background information
   - Be sure to include relevant context and details so that Claude’s response is maximally targeted to be helpful

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "What is marketing? How do I do it?"
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I'm developing a marketing strategy for a new eco-friendly cleaning product line. Can you provide an overview of current trends in green marketing? Please include:
   1. Key messaging strategies that resonate with environmentally conscious consumers
   2. Effective channels for reaching this audience
   3. Examples of successful green marketing campaigns from the past year
   4. Potential pitfalls to avoid (e.g., greenwashing accusations)

   This information will help me shape our marketing approach."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt asks for specific, contextually relevant  information that leverages Claude's broad knowledge base. It provides context for how the information will be used, which helps Claude frame its answer in the most relevant way.

### 6. Use role-playing
   - Ask Claude to adopt a specific role or perspective when responding.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Help me prepare for a negotiation."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "You are a fabric supplier for my backpack manufacturing company. I'm preparing for a negotiation with this supplier to reduce prices by 10%. As the supplier, please provide:
   1. Three potential objections to our request for a price reduction
   2. For each objection, suggest a counterargument from my perspective
   3. Two alternative proposals the supplier might offer instead of a straight price cut

   Then, switch roles and provide advice on how I, as the buyer, can best approach this negotiation to achieve our goal."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt uses role-playing to explore multiple perspectives of the negotiation, providing a more comprehensive preparation. Role-playing also encourages Claude to more readily adopt the nuances of specific perspectives, increasing the intelligence and performance of Claude’s response.


## Task-specific tips and examples

### Content Creation

1. **Specify your audience**
   - Tell Claude who the content is for.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Write something about cybersecurity."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I need to write a blog post about cybersecurity best practices for small business owners. The audience is not very tech-savvy, so the content should be:
   1. Easy to understand, avoiding technical jargon where possible
   2. Practical, with actionable tips they can implement quickly
   3. Engaging and slightly humorous to keep their interest

   Please provide an outline for a 1000-word blog post that covers the top 5 cybersecurity practices these business owners should adopt."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt specifies the audience, desired tone, and key characteristics of the content, giving Claude clear guidelines for creating appropriate and effective output.

2. **Define the tone and style**
   - Describe the desired tone.
   - If you have a style guide, mention key points from it.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Write a product description."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Please help me write a product description for our new ergonomic office chair. Use a professional but engaging tone. Our brand voice is friendly, innovative, and health-conscious. The description should:
   1. Highlight the chair's key ergonomic features
   2. Explain how these features benefit the user's health and productivity
   3. Include a brief mention of the sustainable materials used
   4. End with a call-to-action encouraging readers to try the chair

   Aim for about 200 words."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt provides clear guidance on the tone, style, and specific elements to include in the product description.

3. **Define output structure**
   - Provide a basic outline or list of points you want covered.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Create a presentation on our company results."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I need to create a presentation on our Q2 results. Structure this with the following sections:
   1. Overview
   2. Sales Performance
   3. Customer Acquisition
   4. Challenges
   5. Q3 Outlook

   For each section, suggest 3-4 key points to cover, based on typical business presentations. Also, recommend one type of data visualization (e.g., graph, chart) that would be effective for each section."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt provides a clear structure and asks for specific elements (key points and data visualizations) for each section.

### Document summary and Q&A

1. **Be specific about what you want**
   - Ask for a summary of specific aspects or sections of the document.
   - Frame your questions clearly and directly.
   - Be sure to specify what kind of summary (output structure, content type) you want

2. **Use the document names**
   - Refer to attached documents by name.

3. **Ask for citations**
   - Request that Claude cites specific parts of the document in its answers.

Here is an example that combines all three of the above techniques:

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Summarize this report for me."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I've attached a 50-page market research report called 'Tech Industry Trends 2023'. Can you provide a 2-paragraph summary focusing on AI and machine learning trends? Then, please answer these questions:
   1. What are the top 3 AI applications in business for this year?
   2. How is machine learning impacting job roles in the tech industry?
   3. What potential risks or challenges does the report mention regarding AI adoption?

   Please cite specific sections or page numbers when answering these questions."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt specifies the exact focus of the summary, provides specific questions, and asks for citations, ensuring a more targeted and useful response. It also indicates the ideal summary output structure, such as limiting the response to 2 paragraphs.

### Data analysis and visualization

1. **Specify the desired format**
   - Clearly describe the format you want the data in.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Analyze our sales data."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I've attached a spreadsheet called 'Sales Data 2023'. Can you analyze this data and present the key findings in the following format:

   1. Executive Summary (2-3 sentences)

   2. Key Metrics:
      - Total sales for each quarter
      - Top-performing product category
      - Highest growth region

   3. Trends:
      - List 3 notable trends, each with a brief explanation

   4. Recommendations:
      - Provide 3 data-driven recommendations, each with a brief rationale

   After the analysis, suggest three types of data visualizations that would effectively communicate these findings."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt provides a clear structure for the analysis, specifies key metrics to focus on, and asks for recommendations and visualization suggestions for further formatting.

### Brainstorming
 1. Use Claude to generate ideas by asking for a list of possibilities or alternatives.
     - Be specific about what topics you want Claude to cover in its brainstorming

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Give me some team-building ideas."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "We need to come up with team-building activities for our remote team of 20 people. Can you help me brainstorm by:
   1. Suggesting 10 virtual team-building activities that promote collaboration
   2. For each activity, briefly explain how it fosters teamwork
   3. Indicate which activities are best for:
      a) Ice-breakers
      b) Improving communication
      c) Problem-solving skills
   4. Suggest one low-cost option and one premium option."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt provides specific parameters for the brainstorming session, including the number of ideas, type of activities, and additional categorization, resulting in a more structured and useful output.

2. Request responses in specific formats like bullet points, numbered lists, or tables for easier reading.

   Bad Prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Compare project management software options."
   </prompt>

   Good Prompt:
   <prompt>
   "We're considering three different project management software options: Asana, Trello, and Microsoft Project. Can you compare these in a table format using the following criteria:
   1. Key Features
   2. Ease of Use
   3. Scalability
   4. Pricing (include specific plans if possible)
   5. Integration capabilities
   6. Best suited for (e.g., small teams, enterprise, specific industries)"
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt requests a specific structure (table) for the comparison, provides clear criteria, making the information easy to understand and apply.
  
## Troubleshooting, minimizing hallucinations, and maximizing performance

1. **Allow Claude to acknowledge uncertainty**
   - Tell Claude that it should say it doesn’t know if it doesn’t know. Ex. “If you're unsure about something, it's okay to admit it. Just say you don’t know.”

2. **Break down complex tasks**
   - If a task seems too large and Claude is missing steps or not performing certain steps well, break it into smaller steps and work through them with Claude one message at a time.

3. **Include all contextual information for new requests**
   - Claude doesn't retain information from previous conversations, so include all necessary context in each new conversation.

## Example good vs. bad prompt examples

These are more examples that combine multiple prompting techniques to showcase the stark difference between ineffective and highly effective prompts.

### Example 1: Marketing strategy development

Bad prompt:
<prompt>
"Help me create a marketing strategy."
</prompt>

Good prompt:
<prompt>
"As a senior marketing consultant, I need your help developing a comprehensive marketing strategy for our new eco-friendly smartphone accessory line. Our target audience is environmentally conscious millennials and Gen Z consumers. Please provide a detailed strategy that includes:

1. Market Analysis:
   - Current trends in eco-friendly tech accessories
   - 2-3 key competitors and their strategies
   - Potential market size and growth projections

2. Target Audience Persona:
   - Detailed description of our ideal customer
   - Their pain points and how our products solve them

3. Marketing Mix:
   - Product: Key features to highlight
   - Price: Suggested pricing strategy with rationale
   - Place: Recommended distribution channels
   - Promotion: 
     a) 5 marketing channels to focus on, with pros and cons for each
     b) 3 creative campaign ideas for launch

4. Content Strategy:
   - 5 content themes that would resonate with our audience
   - Suggested content types (e.g., blog posts, videos, infographics)

5. KPIs and Measurement:
   - 5 key metrics to track
   - Suggested tools for measuring these metrics

Please present this information in a structured format with headings and bullet points. Where relevant, explain your reasoning or provide brief examples.

After outlining the strategy, please identify any potential challenges or risks we should be aware of, and suggest mitigation strategies for each."
</prompt>

Why it's better: This prompt combines multiple techniques including role assignment, specific task breakdown, structured output request, brainstorming (for campaign ideas and content themes), and asking for explanations. It provides clear guidelines while allowing room for Claude's analysis and creativity.

### Example 2: Financial report analysis

Bad prompt:
<prompt>
"Analyze this financial report."
</prompt>

Good prompt:
<prompt>
"I've attached our company's Q2 financial report titled 'Q2_2023_Financial_Report.pdf'. Act as a seasoned CFO and analyze this report and prepare a briefing for our board of directors. Please structure your analysis as follows:

1. Executive Summary (3-4 sentences highlighting key points)

2. Financial Performance Overview:
   a) Revenue: Compare to previous quarter and same quarter last year
   b) Profit margins: Gross and Net, with explanations for any significant changes
   c) Cash flow: Highlight any concerns or positive developments

3. Key Performance Indicators:
   - List our top 5 KPIs and their current status (Use a table format)
   - For each KPI, provide a brief explanation of its significance and any notable trends

4. Segment Analysis:
   - Break down performance by our three main business segments
   - Identify the best and worst performing segments, with potential reasons for their performance

5. Balance Sheet Review:
   - Highlight any significant changes in assets, liabilities, or equity
   - Calculate and interpret key ratios (e.g., current ratio, debt-to-equity)

6. Forward-Looking Statements:
   - Based on this data, provide 3 key predictions for Q3
   - Suggest 2-3 strategic moves we should consider to improve our financial position

7. Risk Assessment:
   - Identify 3 potential financial risks based on this report
   - Propose mitigation strategies for each risk

8. Peer Comparison:
   - Compare our performance to 2-3 key competitors (use publicly available data)
   - Highlight areas where we're outperforming and areas for improvement

Please use charts or tables where appropriate to visualize data. For any assumptions or interpretations you make, please clearly state them and provide your reasoning.

After completing the analysis, please generate 5 potential questions that board members might ask about this report, along with suggested responses.

Finally, summarize this entire analysis into a single paragraph that I can use as an opening statement in the board meeting."
</prompt>

Why it's better: This prompt combines role-playing (as CFO), structured output, specific data analysis requests, predictive analysis, risk assessment, comparative analysis, and even anticipates follow-up questions. It provides a clear framework while encouraging deep analysis and strategic thinking.

' ====================================================================
' NovAssistant Workbook Structure
' ====================================================================
' This workbook contains multiple worksheets and VBA modules to create
' a comprehensive novated leasing sales assistant

' ====================================================================
' Worksheet Structure:
' ====================================================================
' 1. Dashboard - Main control center with KPIs and quick actions
' 2. CustomerTracker - Database of all customers and their status
' 3. CallPlanner - Daily call list and schedule
' 4. Templates - Email templates and phone scripts
' 5. QuoteBuilder - Quick quote generator
' 6. LeadAnalytics - Performance metrics and conversion analysis
' 7. Settings - System configuration and API connections

' ====================================================================
' VBA Modules:
' ====================================================================
' 1. OutlookIntegration - Connect with Outlook for email/calendar
' 2. DynamicsIntegration - Sync with Dynamics CRM
' 3. CallAssistant - Call scripting and tracking
' 4. QuoteEngine - Generate customer quotes
' 5. DataManager - Handle data organization and backup
' 6. UIController - Manage ribbon and forms
' 7. AutomationEngine - Task automation and scheduling

' ====================================================================
' Key Functions:
' ====================================================================
' 1. Real-time customer journey tracking
' 2. Automated email generation with templates
' 3. Call scheduling and script prompting
' 4. Quote generation and comparison
' 5. Performance analytics and reporting
' 6. CRM synchronization
' 7. Document generation and management

' ====================================================================
' Workbook Architecture
' ====================================================================

' === DASHBOARD WORKSHEET ===
' The Dashboard worksheet serves as the main interface with:
' - Today's call list and progress tracker
' - Top priority leads requiring attention
' - Recent activity feed
' - Performance metrics (calls made, quotes sent, conversions)
' - Quick access buttons for common actions

' === CUSTOMER TRACKER WORKSHEET ===
' Database structure with columns:
' - Customer ID
' - Customer Name
' - Contact Information (Phone, Email)
' - Current Stage in Journey
' - Last Contact Date
' - Next Action Required
' - Next Action Due Date
' - Vehicle Details
' - Quote Information
' - Notes
' - Status (Hot, Warm, Cold)
' - Assigned To

' === CALL PLANNER WORKSHEET ===
' Daily call scheduling with:
' - Time slots
' - Customer assignment
' - Call purpose
' - Pre-call notes
' - Script selection
' - Post-call outcome tracking
' - Follow-up scheduling

' === TEMPLATES WORKSHEET ===
' Repository of all templates with:
' - Template ID
' - Template Name
' - Template Category
' - Template Text
' - Merge Fields
' - Last Updated

' === QUOTE BUILDER WORKSHEET ===
' Quote generation tool with:
' - Vehicle selection
' - Term options
' - Kilometer allowance selector
' - Tax calculation
' - Comparison visualizer
' - Quick send options

' === LEAD ANALYTICS WORKSHEET ===
' Performance tracking with:
' - Conversion metrics by stage
' - Time-in-stage analysis
' - Call efficiency metrics
' - Success rate by vehicle type

Salary Packaging Arrangement Terms and Conditions
By signing the Vehicle Salary Sacrice Schedule (VSSS), the employee
acknowledges and agrees that any salary sacrice schedule or salary packaging
arrangement provided by SG FLEET AUSTRALIA PTY LIMITED ('SG FLEET') will be
subject to these terms and conditions.
1. DEFINITIONS
(a) 'Automotive Services' means any services provided:
(i) to assist an Employee in locating, conducting price negotiations and arranging
delivery of a new or used vehicle, as selected by the Employee, for a nancial
service product offering;
(ii) to assist with trade-in cars and other products or services or aftermarket
products and services as may be requested by the Employee.
(b) 'Contract Modication' means a document issued by SG Fleet which reects a
variation to the VSSS as agreed between the Employee and SG Fleet.
(c) 'Employee' means the person whose name appears on each page of the VSSS
and under "Employee authorisation".
(d) 'Employer' means the party whose name appears on the VSSS under
"Employer".
(e) 'Employer De-Novation Event' has the meaning given in clause 4(a).
(f) 'Final Schedule' means the document titled "Final Schedule and Tax Invoice
Novated Finance Lease", which forms part of the Lease.
(g) 'Finance Lease Terms and Conditions' means the Finance Lease Standard Terms
and Conditions (Version 10/2023).
(h) 'Indicative Schedule' means the document entitled "Indicative Schedule
Novated Finance Lease", which forms part of the Lease.
(i) 'Lease' means the vehicle lease to be entered into between SG Fleet and the
Employee, comprising the Finance Lease Terms and Conditions, the Indicative
Schedule and the Final Schedule, as novated to the Employer pursuant to a
novation agreement.
(j) 'LeaseGuard' means the optional insurance product selected by the Employee.
(k) 'Salary Packaging Arrangement' or 'SPA' means an effective salary sacrice
arrangement as dened under Taxation Ruling TR 2001/10, for the provision of non-
cash benets to an Employee as agreed between SG Fleet, the Employer and the
Employee and set out in a VSSS under which a proportion of an Employee's salary
is withheld by the Employer and paid to SG Fleet for the purpose of paying the SPA
Expenses.
(l) 'SPA Expenses' includes but not limited to:
(i) the monthly lease rental payments payable in connection with the Lease;
(ii) the monthly package management and administration fees payable to SG
Fleet which have been negotiated with the Employer;
(iii) fuel and uids (including oil) costs invoiced by the fuel supplier in respect of
the vehicle;
(iv) comprehensive insurance and other insurance premiums payable on the
vehicle as requested in writing by the Employee;
(v) scheduled service, maintenance, and repair costs (except where the Employee
has requested a variation to the budgeted cost) for the vehicle payable to an
authorized supplier in respect of the vehicle;
(vi) registration costs and compulsory third-party insurance costs for the vehicle
as requested in writing by the Employee;
(vii) payment for LeaseGuard on the vehicle as requested in writing by the
Employee;
(viii) unscheduled repairs, maintenance and service (including major breakdown
repair) of the vehicle; and
(ix) any other costs or expenses reasonably incurred in connection with the lease
of the vehicle.
(m) 'Vehicle Salary Sacrice Schedule' or 'VSSS' means the document (in a form
provided by SG Fleet) that nominates an amount to be withheld by the Employer
from the Employee's salary for the provision of a specic non cash benet under a
SPA, together with these Salary Packaging Arrangement Terms and Conditions
entitled "Vehicle Salary Sacrice Schedule".
2. WHAT SG FLEET AGREES AND ACKNOWLEDGES
(a) The SPA will be provided to the Employee by SG Fleet in its own right in
accordance with these Salary Packaging Arrangement Terms and Conditions.
(b) Subject to the receipt of payment from the Employer and a valid tax invoice, SG
Fleet will pay the expenses relating to a SPA from the amount paid by the
Employer to pay the SPA Expenses.
(c) Amount on account of goods and services tax (GST) will not be taken into
account in salary deductions for the SPA Expenses unless the Employer has
determined that such GST amounts are to be paid by the Employee. The
occurrence of an Employer De-Novation Event will result in GST being charged
directly to the Employee, this includes (where applicable) the residual value and
any termination amount payable under the terms of the novated vehicle lease.
3. WHAT THE EMPLOYEE ACKNOWLEDGES AND AGREES
(a) The Employee agrees to a proportion of their salary being withheld by the
Employer and paid to SG Fleet for the provision of SPA and payment of SPA
Expenses as detailed in clause 2(b). The salary deduction commences upon vehicle
delivery, and any delay in establishing the salary deduction by the Employer will
result in an additional initial deduction from the Employee's salary.
(b) The Employee acknowledges and agrees that any budgeted cost instalment
specied in the VSSS for a service paid as a budgeted cost is an estimate only.
Acting reasonably, SG Fleet reserves the right to review any SPA Expenses for
which a budgeted cost instalment is payable. If the amount in the VSSS is
insufcient to meet the actual SPA Expenses, the Employee agrees to either:
(i) enter into a Contract Modication; or
(ii) make an additional payment,
as SG Fleet reasonably considers necessary, to avoid a decit in the running
account for that SPA Expense. The payment made by the Employee towards the
additional amount will be allocated rst to pay the SPA Expenses or as
repayment of the amounts owing to SG Fleet (to the extent that SG Fleet has
advanced monies to make payment of any SPA Expenses).
(c) SG Fleet has told the Employee through asking them to give this
acknowledgement that:
(i) it is the Employee's responsibility to ensure that the vehicle is insured at all
times in accordance with the lease terms;
(ii) the VSSS is a binding order and SG Fleet is authorised to order the relevant
vehicle from a supplier on the Employee's behalf. Such order cannot be cancelled
without incurring costs which will include any cancellation charges incurred from
the supplier, the full cost of any accessories ordered and an administration fee
payable by the Employee on demand from SG Fleet;
(iii) the VSSS is subject to SG Fleet's credit and underwriting approval (including
any relevant conditions);
(iv) pre-tax contributions may be applied in respect of the leased vehicle or other
future benet under a SPA that may arise from time to time in respect of that
Employee;
(v) the Employee has requested a post-tax contribution amount to be applied by
the Employer for amount up to but not exceeding the taxable value of the fringe
benet;
(vi) the VSSS includes an estimate of fringe benet tax (FBT) liability based on
information (including estimated kilometres) provided by the Employee. Any
variation to the information provided may result in an adjustment to the
Employee's fringe benets tax liability and therefore the Employee's cost;
(vii) SG Fleet and its related entities may receive payments, discounts, referral
fees, incentives, commissions, origination fees, rebates or other benets from car
manufacturers, car dealers, third party suppliers (including suppliers of insurance
products) and providers of nancial service products and services, Automotive
Services, the facilitation of insurance products or for the management of SPA as
provided by SG Fleet to an Employee and/or Employer. Other volume rebates and
incentives may be received by SG Fleet, and these are linked to performance
targets set by suppliers based on SG Fleet's overall performance across all of its
clients rather than any specic transaction, and may vary from time to time;
(viii) the Employee should form their own assessment about any information
provided to the Employee by SG Fleet, whether the Lease and the SPA is suitable
for the Employee, and whether the vehicle is suitable for the Employee;
(ix) the Employee should consider obtaining their own independent legal,
nancial and taxation advice in relation to the Lease and SPA; and
(x) SG Fleet has not authorized anyone on its behalf to make representations in
respect of, the way in which the Lease or SPA or any payments made by the
Employee under the Lease or SPA will be treated for taxation or accounting
purposes, or in respect of any vehicle.
NAME
Glenn Strother
QUOTE ID
1389422/007

(d) The Employee acknowledges that any delivery date for the vehicle provided is
an estimate only and may be subject to change due to circumstances outside SG
Fleet's control. To the extent reasonably practicable, SG Fleet will provide updates
regarding delivery progress.
(e) It is the Employee's responsibility to inspect the vehicle before taking delivery. If
the Employee is not satised with the condition of the vehicle or if the vehicle does
not meet the specication in accordance with the description in the Indicative
Schedule or Final Schedule, the Employee must not accept the vehicle.
(f) SG Fleet reserves the right to charge an amount in respect of its reasonable
costs if the SPA is varied or terminated early. For example, if the Employee requests
SG Fleet to terminate the Lease earlier than the agreed term. These additional fees
will not apply if such variation is made by SG Fleet to protect its legitimate interest,
including to deal with any regulatory change. Upon request, SG Fleet will provide a
schedule of SG Fleet's standard fees and charges.
(g) If, during the term of the SPA, there is a reduction in the amount of the
Employee's remuneration and the Employee is no longer able to nance the
vehicle through the Employer's remuneration and benets program, then the
Employee agrees to be responsible for all obligations pursuant to any covenant,
liability or responsibility under the SPA, including the obligation to make rental
payments and SPA Expenses.
(h) SG Fleet is not required to pay for any SPA Expenses when SG Fleet has not
received sufcient salary deduction from the Employer. If the amount received
from the Employer is less than the payments SG Fleet is required to pay on the
Employee's behalf to third party service providers, some of the payments to those
third parties will remain outstanding. Upon receipt by SG Fleet of further
deductions from the Employer or where a Contract Modication is agreed
pursuant to clause 3(b), any outstanding payments to third parties will be
prioritised before reimbursements are made to the Employee. SG Fleet may by
notice to the Employer and the Employee, suspend the services to which the
overdue payment relates unless and until all such overdue payments are made to
SG Fleet.
(i) Acting reasonably, SG Fleet reserves the right to refuse to pay a tax invoice or
reimburse any expense if in its reasonable opinion such tax invoice or expense is
not a 'vehicle expense' as dened in the Fringe Benets Tax Assessment Act 1986
(Cth) in relation to the vehicle.
(j) The Employee acknowledges that novated leases are xed term contracts, they
are not intended to be paid out prior to the end of the term. If paid out early, the
payout amount may sometimes be higher than the market value of the vehicle,
and the Employee acknowledges that it will be responsible for the entire payout
amount.
(k) The Employee acknowledges that any surplus monies available at the end of
the lease term will be paid back as taxable salary via the Employer. Pre-tax funds
held by SG Fleet cannot be directly applied to payment of the residual value or
early termination amount.
(l) The Employee conrms that all information they have provided to SG Fleet is up
to date, accurate and complete, including the Employee's current salary and
nancial information, bank account details or changes thereof. Where any
incorrect bank account information is provided or the Employee has not promptly
notied SG Fleet of any changes to bank account details, any cost associated with
recovering or redirecting payments, as well as any bank fees, interest or charges
will be charged to the Employee.
(m) The Employee agrees to notify SG Fleet and the Employer as soon as possible
prior to taking unpaid leave.
(n) SG Fleet's privacy statement sets out the policies on how SG Fleet collects, uses,
stores and discloses credit and personal information. The Employee acknowledges
that if the Employee does not agree to SG Fleet's use of credit and personal
information in the way described in its privacy statement, SG Fleet may be unable
to provide its products and services to the Employee. SG Fleet complies with the
Privacy Act 1988 (Cth)and will manage personal information in accordance with its
privacy policy (available at https://www.sgeet.com/au/privacy-policy). For coaching
and quality assurance purposes, SG Fleet may record telephone calls routed by its
call management system unless callers ask SG Fleet not to.
(o) The Employee has read, understood and agreed to the Employer's policies and
procedures in relation to the remuneration package.
(p) The Employee acknowledges that the residual value, rental amount and
underlying interest rate appearing on the Indicative Schedule are indicative only. If
the value of the vehicle and/or underlying interest rate changes between the date
of quotation and vehicle delivery, the change will be passed on to the Employee.
The nal variables will be conrmed in the Final Schedule, which will be provided
to the Employee upon settlement.
(q) Nothing in this document limits any liability SG Fleet may have to the Employee
under the Australian Consumer Law or under the provisions of any other
applicable legislation where SG Fleet is not permitted to exclude its liability.
4. EMPLOYER DE-NOVATION
(a) SG Fleet will manage the SPA until the earlier of:
(i) the time immediately prior to the expiration or termination of the novated
vehicle lease;
(ii) at SG Fleet's reasonable discretion, the date the Employer ceases to make
contributions to SG Fleet for the payment of the SPA Expenses for any reason;
(iii) the date upon which SG Fleet receives written notice from the Employer that
the Employee ceased to be employed by the Employer;
(iv) the date upon which SG Fleet receives written notice from the Employer that
the Employee has died or, subject to any applicable anti-discrimination law, has
lost mental capacity;
(v) the date agreed by the Employer and the Employee on which the Employer
De-Novation Event will occur, as notied by the Employer to SG Fleet in writing;
(vi) the date SG Fleet reasonably determines that it is no longer able to provide
salary packaging services to the Employer and terminates its provision of salary
packaging services to the Employer, for example in accordance with its
obligations under applicable legislation including but not limited to the Anti-
Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006 (Cth);
(vii) at SG Fleet's discretion, the date SG Fleet reasonably considers that there has
been an adverse change in the Employer's nancial circumstance which has had
a material impact on the Employee's or the Employer's ability to comply with the
nancial obligations (or SG Fleet's ability to assess this) under the SPA or the
Lease or SG Fleet's security risk (or its ability to assess this); and
(viii) at SG Fleet's reasonable discretion, the date Employer becomes unable to
pay their debts as they fall due. (each an “Employer De-Novation Event").
(b) Upon the occurrence of the Employer De-Novation Event:
(i) the Employee will become responsible for all obligations under the novated
vehicle lease (including payment of lease rental and SPA Expenses) arising on
and from the Employer De-Novation Event and the Employer will cease to have
those obligations;
(ii) after payment of all outstanding expenses, any credit balance will be paid to
the Employer and reimbursed to the Employee through the Employer's standard
salary/payroll process. Any debit balance will be payable by the Employer to SG
Fleet and deducted from the Employee through the Employer's standard
salary/payroll process. An excess reimbursement / third party payment
transaction fee may be charged if SG Fleet is required to process excess
reimbursement or third party payment transactions under a SPA. A schedule of
SG Fleet's standard fees and charges is available upon request;
(iii) a reconciliation statement will be provided by SG Fleet to the Employee and
Employer. The Employee acknowledges that the reconciliation statement may be
incomplete due to timing differences between dates upon which SPA Expenses

Your responsibilities
Keeping us up to date
During the period of insurance and at each renewal you must tell us of any of the following changes (for
which we may require you to pay an additional premium to maintain cover):
▼ any change in the business including its permanent discontinuance, insolvency or its being placed in
administration, voluntary administration or having a receiver appointed;
▼ details of any conversion or modification to your vehicle made by someone other than the
manufacturer. For example, if you give your vehicle wider tyres or wheels, or lower its suspension; or
▼ you change your address, your vehicle, your vehicle's garaged postcode or the way you use your
vehicle.
You must tell us
You must tell us at the commencement of your policy and at each renewal if you ('you' does not include an
authorised driver unless they are also an insured) have been:
▼ declared bankrupt;
▼ unable to pay any debts or liabilities as they fell due;
▼ placed in administration or voluntary administration;
▼ had a receiver appointed; or
▼ refused insurance or had any insurance cancelled or declined in the past 5 years; or
▼ convicted of a criminal offence relating to murder, firearms, arson, alcohol, drugs, burglary,
housebreaking, theft, robbery, receiving stolen goods, fraud, criminal or wilful damage or injury or
assault to anyone. However, these convictions do not need to be declared:
▼ if the person was convicted for the offence/s committed whilst under the age of eighteen (18);
and
▼ if the conviction is more than 3 years old.
Your duty of disclosure
You must comply with your Duty of Disclosure when you apply for insurance with us and each time you
renew or alter your cover.
You have a Duty of Disclosure to tell us everything you know or should know, that is relevant to our decision
to insure anyone under the policy, including you, and on what terms.
It includes matters we specifically ask about when you apply for a policy, or renew or alter your policy, and
any other matters which might affect whether we insure you and on what terms.
The information you tell us can affect:
▼ the amount of your premium and your excess
▼ if we will insure you
▼ if special conditions will apply to your policy.
You do not need to tell us of anything which:
▼ reduces the chances of you making a claim
▼ we should know about because of the business we are in; or
▼ we tell you we do not want to know.
If you are unsure it is better to tell us. If you do not tell us something which you know or should know is
relevant, we might reduce a claim, refuse to pay a claim, cancel your policy or, if fraud is involved we can
treat the policy as if it had never existed.
The Duty of Disclosure applies to every person or organisation insured under the policy. If you fail to comply
with your duty of disclosure we may be entitled to reduce our liability under the contract in respect of a claim
or may cancel the contract or both. If your non-disclosure is fraudulent, we may also have the option of
voiding the contract from its beginning.
We appreciate privacy is important to you. We are committed to protecting your personal information. For

Intro
A novated lease is one of the most affordable ways to get a new car.
It's a three-way agreement between you (the employee), your employer, and SG Fleet.
The process starts with you selecting a vehicle, which we can source for you from our large dealer network with access to fle et discounts.
Using this vehicle and some other information such as your salary and expected kilometres, we draw up a package which is dedu cted directly from your pay.
The package includes not just the finance, but all the running costs including petrol, maintenance, insurance, registration a nd tyres.
This creates significant tax advantages since many of these expenses come from your pre -tax salary.
The result is a simple, all-inclusive solution that typically saves you money compared to traditional car ownership or financing methods.
Residual Value & End of Lease Options
At the end of your lease term, there is a residual value owing.
This amount is determined by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) and represents the remaining value of the vehicle.
The residual value will be clearly itemized on your quote.
As you approach the end of your lease (approximately six months out), we'll contact you to discuss your three main options:
Purchase the vehicle outright by paying the residual amount•
Refinance the residual amount over a new term•
Return the vehicle and start a new lease on a different vehicle•
Each option has its advantages depending on your circumstances.
If you love your current vehicle, paying out or refinancing the residual lets you keep it.
If you're ready for something new, you can simply hand back your current vehicle and start fresh with a new lease.
We'll provide guidance through this decision process to ensure you make the choice that best suits your needs.
Employee Contribution Method (ECM) Explained
The Employee Contribution Method (ECM) is how we structure your novated lease to eliminate Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT) liabilit y.
Under the ECM, a portion of your lease payment comes from your post -tax salary.
This post-tax contribution offsets the FBT that would otherwise be payable on the vehicle.
The exact amount required is calculated based on the statutory formula.
The statutory formula requires a post-tax contribution equal to approximately 20% of the vehicle's cost.
For example,
if your vehicle costs $50,000
▫
The annual post-tax contribution would be around $10,000
▫
Divided into your regular pay cycles.
▫
The pre-tax/post-tax split is automatically calculated and optimized for your situation.
You'll see this breakdown clearly on your quote, showing exactly how much comes from each portion of your salary.
This strategic structuring creates maximum tax efficiency while ensuring compliance with ATO requirements.
Running Costs & Account Management
One of the key benefits of a novated lease is how we handle your running costs.
A portion of the repayments made go into an account that you will have access to, to monitor and manage.
Your balance will accrue in your account and will be available for you to spend as you need it.
For example, when you need petrol every week, insurance every month, or servicing every year, there will be money in your acc ount ready for these expenses.
When you need to use these funds, they can be accessed automatically.
-
When you need fuel, you simply swipe your fuel card.
-
We can pay registration directly, as well as your mechanic or tyre providers when the vehicle is serviced.
-
You can also pay for items yourself and seek reimbursement through your online account. Any surplus funds you have not used a re automatically returned at the end of the lease, so you
never lose money that's allocated but not spent.
This system creates both convenience and budgeting certainty - you know exactly what your car is costing you every pay cycle, with no surprise expenses.
Basic Novated Lease Explanations
Knowledge Base Page 1

Tax Benefits Explanation
When the funds are deducted from your pay, there is a strategic split between pre -tax and post-tax dollars. The post-tax deduction fully
offsets Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT), so none is payable. Post-tax typically funds the finance component, while running costs generally come
from pre-tax dollars.
This means you don't pay income tax on petrol, maintenance, insurance, registration, and tyres. On top of this, you also don' t pay GST on
these expenses, saving another 10%. You also don't pay GST on the finance component, further reducing the total cost of the v ehicle.
For someone in the average tax bracket, these combined tax benefits typically save thousands of dollars over the course of th e lease
compared to traditional financing arrangements.
The exact savings depend on your income level, with higher income earners often benefiting even more from the pre -tax advantages.
This strategic structuring creates maximum tax efficiency while ensuring compliance with ATO requirements.
Knowledge Base Page 2

Comprehensive Motor Insurance
Our specialized novated lease insurance offers several advantages over standard retail policies.
Key benefits include:
Full lease payout in case of write-off (no gap between market value and lease payout)•
Open driver policy - no need to list other drivers•
One free windscreen replacement per year•
Emergency repairs covered up to $2,500•
Personal effects covered up to $3,000•
Hire vehicle coverage up to $3,000•
Automatic renewal for continuous coverage•
The most important feature is the "gap protection." With standard insurance, if your car is written off, you may receive only the market value, which could be less than your outstanding lease balance.
Our policy covers the full lease payout amount, protecting you from this potential financial gap.
Our insurance is specifically designed for novated leases, with competitive pricing that's often better than retail policies when you consider the enhanced coverage.
Plus, being part of your salary package means the premiums are paid automatically from your allocated funds.
LeaseGuard Redundancy Protection
LeaseGuard is a specialized protection policy that covers your novated lease payments in the event of involuntary redundancy, providing essential financial security during career transitions.
Key benefits include:
Covers your lease payments for up to 11 months (maximum $15,000)
○
Option to hand back the vehicle after 3 monthly payments if involuntarily unemployed
○
Peace of mind knowing your vehicle and credit rating are protected
○
Seamless integration with your novated lease
○
In today's changing economic environment, LeaseGuard provides valuable protection against unexpected organizational changes.
If your employment situation changes unexpectedly, without LeaseGuard you would remain fully responsible for all lease payments.
With LeaseGuard, your payments are covered, giving you time to secure new employment without financial pressure.
The monthly premium is small compared to the potential benefit, making it a wise investment for most clients. The peace of mind this provides is well worth the modest monthly investment,
especially for those who don't have substantial emergency savings or who work in industries with higher restructuring risks.
LeaseGuard Claims Process
Making a claim on your LeaseGuard policy is a straightforward process designed to provide quick financial relief during a stressful time.
If you experience involuntary redundancy, here's what you need to do:
Contact SG Fleet as soon as possible to notify us of your situation1.
Complete the LeaseGuard claim form (we'll provide this to you)2.
Provide documentation of your redundancy (typically a letter from your employer)3.
Submit the completed form and documentation to our claims team4.
Once received, claims are typically processed within 5-7 business days. If approved, payments will begin immediately to cover your lease obligations. The coverage will continue for up to 11
months or until you find new employment, whichever comes first.
If you decide to return the vehicle after at least 3 monthly payments have been covered, we'll arrange for vehicle collection and finalization of your lease without additional financial obligation.
Throughout this process, you'll have a dedicated support person to help guide you and answer any questions.

Dealer Sale Process
The dealer sale process is the most straightforward way to arrange your novated lease. This
applies when you're purchasing a new or used vehicle directly from a licensed motor dealer.
Key steps in the process:
Select your vehicle and negotiate the price with the dealer1.
Provide the dealer quote to SG Fleet2.
We prepare your novated lease quote based on the dealer pricing3.
Upon your approval, we handle the finance application process4.
Once approved, we generate the purchase order for the dealer5.
The dealer prepares the vehicle for delivery6.
You sign the lease documentation7.
We settle payment with the dealer8.
You collect your vehicle and begin your lease9.
Required documentation:
Dealer quote on letterhead with ABN•
Your driver's license and proof of income (typically 2 recent payslips)•
Signed quote acceptance•
Completed finance application•
The typical timeframe from approved quote to vehicle delivery is 1-3 weeks for in-stock vehicles,
or according to build time for ordered vehicles.
This process minimizes your administrative burden, as we handle most of the communication
with the dealer and all of the financial arrangements.
Private Sale Requirements
A private sale novated lease applies when you're purchasing a vehicle from an individual rather than a
dealer. This might be through platforms like Carsales or private listings.
Required documentation:
Registration papers•
PPSR check (we'll handle this)•
Inspection report (for vehicles over $60K)•
Payout letter (if the vehicle is currently financed)•
Invoice signed by the vendor•
Original tax invoice & proof of payment OR Statutory Declaration•
Statement by Supplier signed by vendor•
Vendor bank details (in the form of a bank statement)•
Your bank details for on-road costs (in the form of a bank statement)•
Current odometer reading•
Process timeline:
Document collection (typically 3-7 days)1.
Finance application and approval (1-5 business days)2.
Settlement preparation (3-5 business days)3.
Payment processing (1-2 business days)4.
Important considerations:
We'll need to contact the seller to obtain certain documents•
If the vehicle is currently financed, we'll need to align with the payout letter expiry date•
Depending on the value and financier requirements, a vehicle inspection may be required•
The PPSR check ensures the vehicle isn't written off, stolen, or encumbered with debt•
While private sales require more documentation than dealer purchases, they often represent good
value and we're experienced in managing this process smoothly.

A Sale & Leaseback arrangement applies when you already own your vehicle outright (with no finance
owing) and wish to lease it back to yourself through a novated arrangement.
Required documentation:
Clear copy of registration papers showing you as the registered owner•
PPSR check showing clear title (we'll arrange this)•

Original proof of purchase OR Statutory Declaration•
Statement by Supplier (template provided)•
Your bank details for payment (in the form of a bank statement)•
Current odometer reading•
Process timeline:
Document submission (3-5 days)1.
Finance application and approval (1-5 business days)2.
Document preparation and signing (2-3 days)3.
Settlement and payment to your account (2-3 days)4.
Commencement of salary packaging arrangements5.
Important considerations:
The vehicle must be owned outright with no current finance•
Vehicle age and condition requirements apply (typically under 7 years old)•
Registration must remain current throughout the process•
Valuation will be based on current market value, not original purchase price•
The Sale & Leaseback option is popular for those who already own a suitable vehicle but want to access
the tax and budgeting benefits of a novated lease. It effectively converts an existing asset into a tax-
efficient arrangement while providing you with a lump sum payment.

Refinance Process
The refinance process applies when you're approaching the end of your current lease term and need to
refinance the residual value.
Key steps in the process:
Contact SG Fleet approximately 3-6 months before your residual due date1.
We'll provide options and a quote for refinancing2.
Upon your acceptance, we'll prepare the refinance application3.
Finance approval is obtained (typically 1-5 business days)4.
New documentation is prepared for the refinance term5.
You sign the new lease documents6.

The refinance creates a new lease term (typically 1-5 years)•
Insurance and running costs are recalculated for the new term•

Vehicle condition and age will be considered during the refinance approval process•
Refinancing is a popular option for those who wish to keep their current vehicle while maintaining the
benefits of novated leasing. It allows you to spread the residual payment over a new term rather than
making a lump sum payment.

Exterior Protection (Hydro Paint Surface Coating)
Our Exterior Protection adds a nano coating to the paint which strengthens and gives a permanent super gloss finish to your vehicle.
Key benefits include:
Protection against bird and bat droppings•
Protection against tree sap and bug splatter•
Resistance to sunscreen damage and environmental contaminants•
Permanent super gloss finish•
Significantly easier cleaning and maintenance•
Lifetime warranty•
When you see a car that's been parked outside for months with faded paint, dirt everywhere, and those dried watermarks, you know
exactly what you don't want.
With our Exterior Protection package, your vehicle is protected against all these negative aesthetic issues.
With just a once-off lifetime application, it will keep your car in showroom condition for the duration of your ownership.
The hydrophobic properties create an easy-clean, low maintenance surface. Engineered with nanotechnology, it produces distinctive
beading which rolls off the surface, helping take away dirt, dust, and road grime without damaging the paint.
This protection helps preserve your vehicle's resale value and provides protection against clear coat delamination, which can be costly
to repair.
Interior Protection (Activ Interior Coating)
Our Interior Protection is a once-off application designed to preserve and protect the interior of your new vehicle against daily
wear and spills.
Key benefits include:
Protection against food and liquid stains•
Prevention of discoloration from UV exposure•
Preservation of that new car aroma•
Protection for all fabric, carpet, vinyl, and leather surfaces•
Lifetime warranty•
Think about having children or passengers in your vehicle - spills, dropped food, and accidents are inevitable.
In an unprotected vehicle, these incidents can lead to permanent staining and damage.
With our Interior Protection, most spills can simply be wiped away without leaving lasting marks.
The coating creates a barrier against UV damage and staining, meaning that all interior surfaces are treated to protect against
discoloration, as well as spills and stains. It also helps prevent the growth of mould and mildew, keeping your vehicle fresh and
hygienic.
This once-off application provides a lifetime of protection, helping maintain your vehicle's interior condition for stronger resale
value when it's time to upgrade.

Carbon Offset Program
Our Carbon Offset program provides financial support for initiatives that directly offset the carbon emissions of your vehicle for the life
of your lease.
Key benefits include:
Neutralize your vehicle's environmental impact•
Support for sustainable projects including:
Wind farms
○

○

•
Monthly contributions that make a real difference•

For environmentally conscious drivers, this program offers a way to enjoy the convenience of personal transportation while mitigating
its environmental impact.
The program calculates your vehicle's emissions based on type and expected mileage, then directs funds to projects that reduce or
capture an equivalent amount of carbon.
This is particularly popular with drivers of larger vehicles who want to reduce their environmental footprint, and for organizations with
sustainability commitments.
The program is independently audited to ensure funds are directed to legitimate carbon reduction initiatives.
The cost is modest relative to your overall lease, but the impact is significant - allowing you to drive with the knowledge that you're
supporting important environmental projects.
Roadside Assistance
Our roadside assistance is a premium service, contracting assistance out to the fastest provider rather than relying on a single
service.
Key benefits include:
Australia-wide assistance, 24/7•
Unlimited callouts with no restrictions•
Emergency accommodation and car rental if needed•
Fastest response time available through multi-provider access•
Coverage in remote areas where other services may not reach•
SG Fleet's roadside assistance differs from normal providers in that we contract the assistance out to the fastest provider at the
time of your call.
Instead of just using one provider and relying on their response time, we can reach out to multiple providers and secure the fastest
possible response.
Many roadside assistance policies may not cover you in the event of a breakdown in some regional areas.
SG Fleet roadside assistance provides truly Australia-wide coverage, giving you peace of mind no matter where you travel.

and more serious mechanical issues.
